description:
Jo and Enki are super nice. 

I didn't know this bar is hitting their 10th year anniversary. They're pretty cool and hella friendly.

I'll definitely go back!
author: Dan Mark D.

description:
After dinner, my group of four stopped by Mini Bar. We arrived in Friday, August 10th around 10pm. The bar is fairly small and it was super crowded, so we just stood by the bar.

Ended up getting the Cocktail of the Week, which was the Hanky Panky: buffalo trace, luxardo cherry liqueur, lemon ($9) and a few Makers Mark Manhattans: served up garnished with luxardo cherry ($9). Unfortunately, because it was so crowded, we just had the round and left. We wanted something a little more chill and this spot was too loud and boisterous for us. Plus, there was no open seating.

True to it's name as it's a mini / small bar. I like more laid back lounges, so this wasn't really my scene. Maybe on a slower night, but on a Friday, it was too crowded for me.
author: Elena N.

description:
Great space, but rude bartender. I visited Mini Bar in the early-ish evening on a Sunday and it was fairly empty. I sat at the bar, asked for a grapefruit juice with well tequila, and the bartender essentially shamed me. He basically said "you don't want that" and his friend sitting at the bar laughed.

I wouldn't order well liquor if I planned to sip, but it's perfectly acceptable in mixed drinks. Especially if you're only having one. I don't know why he thought he could talk down to me--perhaps if I were an older male customer he would have been more courteous. Maybe he was just a total snob or trying to make a few more dollars (as my bartender friend mused when I relayed the story)--maybe both. At any rate, I was uncomfortable and won't be back. As another reviewer said, who apparently was also mocked for no reason, there are plenty of other bars with better service.
author: A E.

description:
I'm surprised there aren't many bars around this section of Divisadero. In any neighborhood I'm in, I strive to visit all the popular spots. Mini Bar SF was a typical dive bar, and my experience was a little disappointing. Not sure what I expected, but the reviews on Yelp are generally positive.

For starters, there's not much space in here, and the bench seating (though well-cushioned) is all tattered. Keep walking deeper into the bar to find the small space where the bartender resides. He was dismissive on our visit, but it was a slow Sunday, so I guess I can't blame him.

That day, there was a matador cocktail special with tequila, lime, and pineapple. Right up my alley. Also our high school mascot was a matador, so I felt obligated. Overall the vibe is super chill, the music is fun, and it's dog friendly. Not a bad bar, but not a great one either. I'm guessing almost everyone in here is a regular that lives close by.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
The stars must have been aligned.  Even though the bartender was way too young to know such classic rock, her playlist said the opposite.  When she shared with us that this was indeed her personal playlist, we were awed.
From the Doors to Joni Mitchell, this mixologist knew her craft as well as her classic rock.  Very cool.  
The martinis were chilled beautifully, shaken and served up with a twist.  The vibe is neighborhood- y mellow.  The art work on the wall added to the local, SF ambiance.
So glad to have found you Mini Bar SF.
"You're just what I needed" tonight.  (The Cars)
Clap! Clap! Clap!
author: Thomas D.

description: I've been here more than once. More than a few times. I wouldn't say I'm a regular, but more like an aspiring regular. What I can say is that the clientele (regulars) are friendly. The staff is attentive without being overbearing. The scene is fun. You're likely to see a pup or two in the room and always some interesting art on the walls.
author: Nat S.

description:
I like the art and that they take credit cards. But I question how welcoming or inclusive the place is, as I'd written about in an earlier, more-reactive post. On a recent visit with my soon-to-be wife and local friends, as I was standing up to leave, someone pushed me - hard and said nothing as they proceeded through the bar. When I turned around and said, in a normal-person voice: 'use your words', expecting an 'excuse me' or similar, I got yelled at by someone identifying themselves as the owner. 

The 'owner' then called me names, said something about 'this isn't a bar for you people' and made the bouncer kick me out. Again, this is because I questioned his right to shove me in a rush to cross the narrow, crowded space without any kind of cursory 'behind you' / 'excuse me' / 'sorry buddy' thing one'd expect. Even the bouncer gave me a shrug, knowing I'd done nothing wrong but stand in the way of someone who's clearly high on some privileged, bar-owner buzz that I interrupted. 

Maybe he was having a bad day, but this still feels like not a hospitable way to treat people. I can go on about how the place is filled with cigarette smoke or how the furniture is taped up, but I actually like that in my local dive. I just don't understand why I got insulted in front of my friends for politely standing up for myself. Does that sound fair to you?
author: Alex S.

description:
This is a great little neighborhood bar, sort of your Diviz Dive bar here on Divisadero. Has a few booths up front, a room in the back, and a bar in the middle. Mostly regulars and neighborhood types. 

They make strong drinks at low prices. We had a Hendricks Tonic and Johnny Walker on ice for $15 total, on a Sunday evening. They had an everyday HH until 7pm special: PBR and a shot of Jamison for $8! With that combo and price, could skinny jeanned, beanie chapeau'd hipsters be far away? 

Actually, there were some in here already!
author: Wanugee N.

description: It seemed like a nice little hole in the wall place, but the bartender (Paul) wouldn't serve our ladies because he disagreed with a civil political conversation they had with another customer. Furthermore, instead of just being honest and giving us the true reason he wouldn't serve them, he accused them of being drunk. Pretty lame.
author: George K.

description: This is a great neighborhood bar and I love all the bartenders. So much fun to stop by after work, say hi, and have a drink. I will come and hang out for hours (alone or with coworkers) or just take a quick drink and everyone is always so nice and fun to talk to. If I ever leave the city this will be a bar I will remember along with all the bartenders, a cool old-vibe SF bar.
author: Aili P.

description:
You know I love this hood! I will always have mad love and respect for this hood, my old stomping grounds!

There are super friendly bartenders (and thanks for carding me! WOOT)!
There are beers on tap, beers by the bottle, wine and bubbly and some other spirits, too! Prices are quite reasonable and won't break the bank.

It's a cozy and friendly neighborhoody place, where 1 or maybe 2 or 3 may know your name. If not, everyone here is so casual and chill, you could strike up a convo with someone new.

Seating in the front and back lounge area with few tables, and about 10 bar stools at the bar.

You may see a dog or two, here, as it's pet friendly. What is there not to love?

I've only been here during the weekdays, so can't speak to how it is on Friday or Saturday nights.

I'll be back Mini Bar! Cheers and hope to see y'all there soon!
Happy 2016!
author: Gill C.

description: Seemed like a good place to grab a drink. Unfortunately, the bartender (Paul) didn't seem to like the vibe our girls brought into the place, being that it was Fourth of July and our girls decided to be a bit patriotic and for some reason the bartender didn't appreciate it. So he refused to serve the girls any drinks because he thought our girls were to intoxicated, but in reality he wasn't comfortable with our girls patriotism that night. Pretty petty if you ask me def won't be returning here anytime soon.
author: Gustavo V.

description: Best little local bar in town. Friendly good people work there. Love it! They have Pliny the Elder and you can bring your pooch in there is it is well behaved. A friend lost a bag in there and they kept it behind he bar for him too
author: Michael P.

description: Walked in to grab drink, a patron had strong views about life, had a lively debate with him and proceeded to enjoy the night. The bartender was not amused with a colorful conversation and refused my party to enjoy a good time. This bar does not accept freedom of speech. DO NOT ATTEND if you have any views of the world.
author: Christine G.

description:
Sportsbar-ambience, good for baseball and basketball fans...

The whole insider is illuminated by the gigantic flat screen that successfully kills any kind of comfortable atmosphere. 

Especially since all other lights are kept super dim. Which is a pity since one has problems really seeing the plenty of artworks on the walls in the flickering light of the ongoing baseball game...

The second star only because the do serve ok sized drinks.
author: Axel B.

description:
It's one thing to dislike a customer for some mysterious reason, and another to completely humiliate them in front of other customers. The bartender mocked me (Donald Trump style) when I asked to close out my tab.

There are other bars down the street where, chances are, you can actually enjoy yourself and not leave feeling like half a person.
author: Mich L.

description:
Mini Bar is totally under the radar in a busy flourishing neighborhood. The gentrification of the Divisadero corridor has left the established bars alone for the most part. 

When you walk in to Mini Bar you get a funky cross section of the people in the hood. Some older, some younger but really just never know. The last time we went in the bar tender was making Paloma (grapefruit ,salt, lime juice, sugar, club soda and tequila) for someone else and it looked great. I see people complaining about the drinks not being good and this being a dive bar. It's all true to some degree. They have only a few beers on tab but the beers they have are good.

It's a dive of a bar and its perfect. The bartender knows how to make good drinks, there is usually not a huge crowd and the music isn't too loud. You could have a nice conversation, a couple drinks and life is good. And it's not expensive.
author: Ben M.

description:
Meh. We came here late one night while looking for something open and not too crowded. I always like to ask bartenders at cocktail bars to surprise me with something good. I've never had an issue at Rye, Redford, or similar cocktail bars with that request. Most bartenders see it as a way to be creative and try something different. You would have thought I asked this girl to solve a quadratic or something-- deer in the headlights. Don't put "cocktails" on your window if your bartenders don't feel comfortable making them. Drinks are cheap...lots of bottled beers, maybe 5 on tap? 

There's cool local art on the walls at least. Very narrow space. A back room with couch and some chairs. Clientele is white, hipster, tattooed, pierced, etc.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Solid bar. Came in here for shelter from the rain while waiting for friends to arrive before seeing You Won't open for Lucius at The Independent. 

They didn't have mint for a mojito and didn't have Malibu for a Malibu pineapple so I ended up with Bacardi Pineapple that tasted like ass. At least it was only $6! Definitely a no frills kind of bar. No cocktail menu but plenty of beer selections. 

Love the art on the walls and you can tell a lot of regulars frequent this place since it seemed like everyone around me knew the bartenders. Love the fact they played Tom Petty as soon as I walked in!
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Came here with some friends and had a wonderful time.  The bartenders were accommodating and helpful.  I tried Fernet for the first time and shared some rounds with our group.  The selection was robust and the bartenders took the time to explain the drinks.

The place was not too crowded for a Saturday night.  They do not take credit cards but there is a cash machine.  This was a blessing in disguise as it prevented us from ringing up a fairly large tab!
author: Johnny V.

description:
I came here for the first time last month and the best word I can use to describe it is "divey". This is the type of place that has super cheap drinks (whoo) but where you're afraid to set your elbow on the table because it's sticky with years of accumulated beer. 

We sat by the round table by the door and beware, it's really tippy. Throughout the course of the night we upended 3 different drinks (a bottle of beer and 2 glasses of wine) on ourselves because of this. And no, it wasn't just because we were drunk :) 

That said, the bouncer, who witnessed the scene, was super nice and gave us replacement drinks on the house. They also stuffed a wad of napkins under the table leg and we had a much more stable experience after that.

Personally there are some other bars in the area that I much prefer if you're looking for a few casual and reasonably priced drinks, Fly Bar and The Page being two of them. But this also seems like a local favorite and if you don't mind the divey atmosphere, go for it.
author: Lindsey B.

description:
It's been awhile, but Mini Bar is still holding strong and still just as inviting and charming.

I adore that despite the intimate size of Mini Bar, that you can still hear yourself and your friends. Their back lounge area is absolutely adorable and so what's up. With casual laid back couch seating, it's such a divine secluded space for gathering with a bigger sized group. 

Mini Bar really captures Divisadero street beautifully. The crowd is always mellow and diverse and I appreciate they still display local art and have built up a true local following since their opening a couple of years back. 

Mini Bar's garnered big love in this hood.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
A no fuss bar serving straightforward drinks. When I asked for a drink menu she told me they don't have one. You ask for what you want and they will do their best to accommodate. 

Whiskey Sour and Gin & Tonic only $5 a piece when we went 

Overall Thoughts

No craft cocktails but still a decent place to grab drinks at a reasonable price
author: Eddie W.

description: Genevieve is a great barkeep and the place is the perfect local bar. It's dark, but not too dark. They play good music which fills the room but isn't too loud. It's a great little bar but tables to spread out onto. Happy hour till 7p is $5 well drinks, $2.50 tecate and if you're lucky they might even give you some chips and Quesa.
author: David A R.

description: After being shamed out of Bar 821 down the street for (gasp!) having the audacity to order a vodka drink, my friend and I slunk down the road to Mini Bar. So glad we did! This is the chill, laid-back vibe I was searching for, but with friendly staff and a much more comfortable environment. We were lucky enough to snatch one of the couches in the back room, which made for great conversation and just enough privacy. The music selection was stellar, with many genres and styles which sparked many discussions about Motown, the evolution of U2, the film "20 Feet from Stardom", and how Aretha is still relevant today. I would definitely come here again when I'm in the area, and I suggest it for anyone looking to have a casual evening out with great friends in a welcoming environment.
author: Vanessa B.

description:
It's not as small as the name makes it seem - but it's not big.  Booth seating in the front and like 10 bar stools otherwise.  Probably like 400-500sq ft?

Nothing spectacular about this place.  It's just a small bar.  I would ever choose to go there....just ended up there due to friends.  It just doesn't offer anything different or any one good thing to hang its hat on....

I guess the name in kinda good...?  Kinda....
author: Arthur Y.

description: Really great little bar! Looks a bit divey when you first walk in, but it's actually totally clean and friendly. The female bartender acknowledged us immediately and was super attentive when we needed replacements. They had lots of cool art on the walls from a local tattoo artist, they played decent music, and drinks were pretty cheap ($6 greyhound, $4 beer). Definitely stopping back in next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Some of the best bars and restaurants are on Divisadero and Mini Bar holds its own as the alternative to the fancy spots down the street. While the other places have mood lights and fresh fruit lining the counter Mini Bar takes it back to old school beers and hard cocktails. 
You come here when you want to find some Divis locals or just some eccentric SF transplants. The bar feels a little grungy and dirty but that's exactly what you want in a place like this. No need to get dressed up they will treat you like family and the crowd is a little older which if you don't want to be surrounded by 21 year olds is a great feeling. The music is a great mix covering all decades when I was there I heard a bit of 90's rock and some country on top of that. The one bartender was great when we were there and its quiet enough that you don't have to yell over each other to hear a conversation.
 The bar holds up to its name as you enter there are a few scattered tables and one narrow hallway to the back. You are going to get nice and intimate at Mini Bar. It's also a great place to watch a game or two as there locals are into the SF sports scene and get into what's going on. As your make your way past the bar there is another seating area in the back. There are a couple of couches in that area and if you do need to sit and spread your legs this is the place to do it. The place is very pet friendly as well so don't be surprised to see quite a few dogs lining the floor taking in the music as well. 
Really the only negative to this place it can be hard to find a seat and when that happens you have to stand and when that happens you block up the entire place so it can be a little much. I was there on a Monday night I can't imagine what it's like on a Friday night. Overall if you want to avoid the posh neighboring bars and just kick back and have a beer. Mini bar despite its size is more than up to the task.
author: Nick R.

description:
Good stiff drinks, friendly bartenders, love that you can bring your fluffy loved ones with you while you grab a glass of your favorite drink. For a Friday night, it was still low key and few places to sit. I would definitely give this place another shot for another shot!! 
FYI - parking is terrible around this neighborhood. I should have taken a cab or a muni!!
author: Claudine V.

description: This is a great no frills bar. Small friendly, great bartenders with a nice pouring hand. What more could you want? Always feel  welcome. Great art, great vibe... Hella thankful for a bar like mini ...also the drink prices are good too! Oh yeh, it's never crowded cause it's mini.
author: she o.

description:
Good prices, well-made drinks, a back room lounge with often-bizzarre art and comfy couches, and board games! (If that's your thing. I recommend Cards Against Humanity.) I think I love Mini Bar a little more every time I visit.

This place has the mellow, laid-back neighborhood-y feel that I really appreciate in a bar. Fantastic place for a date, catching up with friends, even reading a book. It's fast becoming my base of operations when doing anything on or around Divisadero.
author: Connor Skye R.

description: Mini Bar is right. This place is tiny, and the clientele leaves something to be desired. The people are fairly grody (literally dirty), and they bring dogs into the bar, which is a bear, because walking around is difficult enough as it is. Their drink menu is extensive, but there's just nowhere to really stand around or sit. I wasn't feeling this place at all.
author: Danny C.

description: sorry, no more Pliny the Younger here as of 02/15. But they do have Pliny the Elder and it's still a cool bar
author: Steve M.

description:
Nice neighborhood bar. Good drink specials daily. I went tonight, and while it started slow (at 5PM) it picked up nicely by 7PM. They had Pliney the Elder bottles (16 oz) for $4 a pop - good deal. The well drinks and beers were also a buck off during happy hour.

The crowd started mellow, locals, but grew nicely. I ended up chatting up the girl next to me that was from the same tiny town as me, and had a good time. Overall, this place is very nice.

Summer, the bartender, is extremely sociable and makes a good drink. Reason enough to come for a few. And the close proximity to the Independent makes it nice.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Wander in, seemed like an interesting place to check out. Quickly realized that the fact that the bartender makes eye contact with you has no bearing on the fact that you'll be ignored, repeatedly for whoever shows up after.

If you're the person that gets served ahead of everyone else, it's a cool place, otherwise figure out how to get cozy with the bartender before going there.
author: Timur A.

description: This is my favorite neighborhood artbar. I almost hate to give it a review because I would like to keep washed masses out...but, I really appreciate the monthly changes in displays of 4-6 local artists...any establishment that supports the arts, especially local artists gets two thumbs up from me!!!
author: Darin L.

description:
I think Mini Bar opened shortly before I moved to NOPA, and whenever I'm doing the bar scene on Divis I attempt to stop in here, but the place is always so crowded (I guess that means they're doing something right!).  

Well, I had a friend in town this past weekend who insisted on drinking hard alcohol for her birthday, so we went this past Sunday.  Luckily, the place wasn't crowded and we were able to sit at a table.

I really like the loungy feel this place has & it's a big plus that they serve (high quality) hard alcohol, unlike most places in the neighborhood.  I thought the drinks we had were decently priced ($7 for Makers & De Serrano), especially considering they have virtually no competition from other bars and could probably charge a buck or two more per drink if they really wanted to.

I'm not sure how often the bouncer who was there on Sunday works the door, but he was great!  He was very friendly (he took several pictures for my friend's birthday) and even played a little harmonica for us.  

Even though we were there on a Sunday and the place closed at midnight, I did notice that they stay open 'til 2 on Friday & Saturday.  This should be a standard thing,  but I have noticed that some bars in this neighborhood close early on weekends, so this made me happy when I saw this.  I really liked this place, and I may even be willing to the brave the crowd to stop in for a drink or two in the future :)
author: George A.

description:
Wow this bar is really "mini!" 

Sis and I went here after dinner at Bar Crudo. Place was packed from the street festival. I had to literally squeeze my way onto the bar to get our drinks. One plus = they serve Hanger One (the original) so I got my usual: OJ + Hanger One and sis had a Guiness. Total for our two drinks: $14! Yah I was shocked! In SF, $14 for two drinks - WOW!

We chatted with some Europeans (very intense discussion about Pottery Barn!) and once my bro-in-law arrived, we left. 

Will probably stop by here again when we're out roaming this district.
author: Cath M.

description: The name says it all. This is a MINI bar! This place is so small!! The bar was dead on a Saturday. We got there about 1:15am but usually places are still packed. This place was like a ghost town. People were sitting there looking somber. The music was turned way down low (actually I'm not even sure if I heard any music playing). It was pretty lame and just was not where I wanted to be at all. Not sure how this place stays in business.
author: Nikki P.

description:
I loved this spot! Great neighborhood feel and just big enough. It's cozy and I was lucky enough to get a couch in the back "lounge" area and it was just intimate enough for a good conversation without being stuffy. I tend to come to bars with friends to catch up over a drink and hate the loud drone that accompanies many hot spots, minibar was the perfect in-between.

Decent drink selection, I had two G&Ts for a whopping $5 each that left me stumbling home - not sure if I'm the lightest weight ever or what, but the pours seemed to be pretty generous. 

I'll definitely be back here and pull up a chair and stay awhile - if I can get one.
author: Courtney A.

description:
Good for a mini date. Wee bit extra privacy because of the lighting and nook in back. First time I went here was for predrinks before getting dinner at Nopa. It was an exceptional night that began very unassumingly. 
4 stars plus 1 because they have Guinness on tap!
author: Janet D.

description: One can get a proper drink at Mini Bar, if a proper drink is what one hankers for. In fact, it's more of a head-down, proper drink kind of place than the hip, urban lounge it might portray itself to be. It is certainly not the most friendly bar I've ever sat at, but it is populated by locals, and there's always someone interesting next to you, whether you want to talk to them or not.
author: Joe V.

description:
I'm on a roll of comparative reviews today.. But that's what Yelp is about, right? It's about standing in front of two doors and picking the right one.

I LOVE Mini Bar! I've never had a bad drink, a bad night or a bad experience here! 

It's very small, so it get crowded, however it's crowded with people I don't mind being around. 

The bartenders are incredibly skilled. Every time I've been here, which has been quite a few times, I've asked for a drink in loose terms and let them make me something.. You know, "I'd like something warming and Whiskey based, not too sweet, not too heavy on the Whiskey, maybe along the lines of a Blood and Sand, but different".. and BAM! I'd get EXACTLY that and LOVE IT!

Also, it's dog friendly, and has a great little sofa filled lounge area in the back!

Can't go wrong here!
author: Liza P.

description:
Small and cozy.  Dim and warming.  Not sure if it's my crowd.  

$4 for a bottle of Hoegarden, which we thought would be draft.  Oh well, bad choice.  They had a bar dog running around, which I thought was weird, but I guess it's fun if you're a regular.  

Disliked the fact that everyone was so close and every guy would touch you every time they walk by.  Can't say too much since I only stayed for about 15 minutes.
author: Nancy S.

description:
Bar 821 was closed on a Tuesday evening for some odd reason, so my coworkers and I went to Mini Bar SF. It was only 5:30pm so the crowd was small and gathered around the bar. My first impression was how clean everything was with plenty of seats. The bar is super chill with 3 big ol' dogs just chilling by their owners. I think I was distracted by the dogs more than anything else.

Good thing about this bar is they allow outside foods. We bought two pizzas from Little Star Pizza right across the street and munched away.

Great selection of beer along with Pliny the Elder and Damnation on tap. My boyfriend would love this place! Not many people sell Russian River Beers on tap or at all...

I'm still dying to try Bar 821, but if you just want a place to chitchat and eat, this is place is great. Oh, and bring your doggy ;]
author: Rosanne L.

description: Stiff drinks, interesting art, friendly bartenders. Not too crowded either so great place to shoot the poop.
author: George K.

description:
I absolutely love that Mini Bar is right down the street from my house.

Although I'm not a regular (and I can tell that they definitely do have their regulars), the place is a gem to have in the neighborhood.  Initially self-advertised as "the only full bar for awhile", the bar is not limited to the beer/sake selection that Fly Bar, 821, and other bars in the area are limited to.

The service is awesome- the bartender lady (who Ialways seems to be working everytime I come through) is on point and very attentive to her patrons.  

Several times, they've had a recession friendly drink special for people on a budget- the last one I can remember was a pabst and jameson shot (I think) for something like $5 - $8.  Great value, and definitely helps me convince my friends who are trying to watch their spending to grab a drink on a tuesday night.  

Big plus:  You could get 4505 chicharonnes as a bar snack for $3.50.
author: Clarissa P.

description:
it certainly is Mini. The place bottle-necks easily but folks are pretty nice so it's rare you'll get rammed by a chrome bag or over-sized "put a bird on it!" tote.

I adore Molly, she is always very sweet always says hello and serves you quickly. Everyone that works there is very nice and laid back. 

I do not recommend getting a Trumer if they are still serving them in the test tube-looking glasses. Because the bar is small and people gotta push past you they are a prime target for getting spilled.

Often there is really nice art there, if it's cheesy or awful it's usually because the owners are giving locals a break...and come on, in a town like SF, that's a really kind thing to do.
author: chandra g.

description:
I pretty much love this bar & it would be my local if I lived in town.  

It's full of regular, friendly, cool, nice people.  Both times I was here last week I struck up a conversation with a neighbour in the backroom.

I went to Russian River night during beer week and I had a great time.  We arrived at open, so there was plenty of Younger to go around and I loved the flight of RR beers.

I also LOVE the artwork that was on display in February 2011 in the back. I was less excited about the photos in the main space but the Adrianna Bamber Phantasmagoria stuff was really interesting and awesome (and reasonably priced).  I probably should have bought one.  I kind of have didn't-buy-regret.

I will be back here everytime I visit Kat F.
author: sarah l.

description: Generally a cool bar, but now seems to be overrun with dogs....talking real dogs. Seems like this is the bar to come to with your dog in tow.
author: Dilly M.

description:
This is a great addition to the neighborhood. They have amazing selection of beer local as well as import. The drinks are good too. The bar tender will work with you just let her know what your choice of alcohol is and she will create something for you.
.
author: Subhash J.

description:
Part bar, part lounge, part art gallery.
Tiny.
Great crowds.
Awesome bartenders.
Home made Bloody Mary mix.
Dogs Allowed.

What's not to love?
author: Yeeman N.

description:
Cool spot! Friendly and funny bartender, down to earth patrons, dogs wondering about (yes, more than one), and a back room that's perfect for groups, if you can snag it.

Good after-work happy hour hang out, and it has a full bar unlike most other spots in the area.  Winning!
author: Emille L.

description: Stiff drinks, interesting art, friendly bartenders. Not too crowded either so great place to shoot the poop. I liked it!
author: Christine P.

description:
Whenever I'm in the area I always drag whomever I'm with here! Always a great selection of art from local artists, and great bartenders who are always on top of their game. Last time I was here I had a "strawberry lemonade" drink with white rum. OMG. I had two of those and I was done! However I guess it's not on the menu because I've been before and a few of the bartenders had no idea what I was talking about. 

plenty of seating, decent bathrooms, and a cute little back room with christmas lights and some interesting mixed media pieces right now. Decently priced drinks and a great atmosphere!
author: Amanda S.

description:
Great neighborhood bar.

They serve Pliny the Elder, which is one of my favorite beers. 

cool space, a bit divey, fun, nice vibe, good date spot.
author: Jordana C.

description:
One of the few Divis bars that serve liquor (others being The Page, Wazemia, Madrone, and recently 821 Bar) -- an automatic one star boost -- Mini Bar is the quintessential neighborhood with a dash of scene. Art  of varying quality adorns the walls, changing over monthly (I think). 

There's not much seating due to the long geometry of the bar. Booths line one side of the wall which make for good art viewing but you sit in a row with your friends which is bad for convo but great for a photo ops. Think A Clockwork Orange's Korova Milk Bar scene featuring Alex and droogs posting and staring. So maybe Mini Bar seating is better for photo ops than conversing. Tell your camera happy, FB posting peeps wassup!

If you're lucky enough to snag the back room, grab it. This smoking room sans smoking offers comfy, couches for intimate lounging and chatting. 

A friend's had problems with a door man but I haven't and find the bar staff nice. 

Prices are quite fair. Top shelf whiskey -- bulliet -- for $6. Quality drafts for $4. Mini Bar gives a sense of class at dive bar value. I like that. I like Mini Bar.
author: Quentin J.

description:
Why is it called this?
There are no mini objects.
Good beers & specials.
//
Came here for a drink,
Friday Happy Hour time
Not too crowded then.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Hey all!
You know me....
The drunk one that only spills her drink while being sober... TWICE!
You know the short and loud asshole that loves your bar, it's bartender, it's bouncer and it's costumers!
I love walking in to a bar where I can find the same people every night, gives me that warm and fuzzy feeling ( in a non sexual way).... 
Good selection of beer and great drinks.
Awesome bartenders and bouncers.
I am sick but I might be able to get my ass down there for just ONE ... just ONE more drink!

peace out!
author: cecilia k.

description: Thought this place looked great from the outside. Went in on a Saturday afternoon, ordered 2 happy hour margaritas and could barely take a sip they were so sweet. Asked the bartender to trade them out for a beer and a vodka/soda. She didn't apologize, smirked instead, andgave me a beer and a soda water (no vodka!). Won't be back again.
author: Megan D.

description: I had a very bad moment in that place. Unfriendly service, the place was okay but the drinks not that good. I don't recommend.
author: Thomas L.

description:
I've recently started going here for drinks before shows at the Independent.  The bartenders have been quick to serve orders, even when they're busy.  The draft selections here don't really suit me, so I've mostly had mixed drinks and have been happy with the pours, and one of the female bartenders made some of the best martinis I've had in months.  

The ambiance is nice.  When I walked in for the first time, I was afraid it would be a bit snooty and pretentious, but it's far more casual than it appears from the street, and both the staff and the patrons have been very friendly each time I've visited.  There is a nice little back room that is often empty - it's perfect for groups and makes it easy to carry conversations over drinks even when the rest of the bar is crowded and loud.
author: Heidi M.

description:
I've had mixed experiences here. Sometimes it's nice and chill - I've had some great conversations in the back area with other folks - but sometimes it's full of douche-bags trying to be trendy in da citay. 

Mixed drinks are mixed - sometimes perfect, sometimes not, so I stick with either vodka and tonic, wine or beer. Can't screw that up. Bartenders friendly - I think they are all co-owners - the lady with the curly hair is especially good. 

I like the art. Sometimes it's disturbing, sometimes it's cool, sometimes it's a kind of "I could do that!" type. But it's rotating and that's cool. 

So, try it out. If you are put off by the crowd, try again another day. That's what I say...
author: Mi M.

description:
This place is too hip for me but they let me in the door anyway :)

The bartender was extremely helpful in assisting me with a low or zero calorie drink option. I ended up with a Vodka Soda and the scale still went down this morning! According to her it is what the Queens and Models in NYC drink. Take it from her, she knows what she's doing.

My friend had a mixed drink of some complex sort she was able to whip up splendidly.

I cant wait to come back. This place is exactly what I want in my neighborhood bar.
author: Katherine B.

description: I usually love Mini Bar. Great local art, great music, vibe, etc. But you guys really need to reconsider the bartender you had on July 14th in the evening. Rude, lousy hosting and general unpleasantness. When I go into a bar to spend my hard earned cash, I expect at minimum a basic level of customer service. I used to bartend so i don't need someone to be a suck up. Just don't be a wanker. I'll go back but not if she's at the bar.
author: Jim E.

description:
Whenever my group of friends is sort of wavering or indecisive about where to go in the Panhandle/Lower Haight/Divisadero area, Mini Bar always ends up being our choice. It's got a lively, interesting mix of people, good drinks, and quick service. However, I wouldn't go here in a group of more than 4, as this place is just too small. 

Mini bar is indeed mini. Finding a space to sit is usually out of the question, as there are only 2 or 3 small tables in the front, a cozy lounge area at the back, and about 8 seats at the bar. Even standing can be hazardous, as the place is so narrow there's basically nowhere to stand without sort of blocking traffic. But it is a bar, after all, so if this is a dealbreaker for you, you're going to have a hard time finding a good drink in this town. 

This is one of the only bars (maybe even the only bar?) in the area that serves hard liquor, which probably explains why it's always crowded. It serves no food, so dogs are welcome and almost always present... my pup loves to snooze under the bar stools when we're here. Mini Bar's walls showcase work by local artists, the quality of which ranges from "meh" to "wow." 

Pros: hard liquor, good service local art, dog friendly
Cons: tiny, loud
author: Lauren K.

description:
The too-cute name of the bar concerned me, as well as the fact that while walking down Divisadero to meet my pal here I observed that this formerly grotty thoroughfare is swiftly transforming into Valencia Street 2.0.  Got plans to start your own "artisan" salumeria/cupcake bakery/brinery?  Best grab a storefront here post haste.  My sad, rundown Western Addition, what have they done to you?!  I digress.  

Fortunately, my worries were for naught.  This is a totally laid back neighborhood bar, not too rife with hipster fashion victims.  The bartender was awesome and very friendly.  Plus - what earns this bar its fifth star - they have Pliny the Elder, my current best beer in the known universe in 14 oz. bottles for six American dollars!  Dude!  Run, don't walk.  I'm thinking I'll go back after work today for Friday night sloppy time!  Yay!
author: Chris J.

description: We live in the neighborhood and stopped in recently to try this place.  We asked the bartender what he could make with mescal, and he gave us an annoyed look, said he didn't know and added "well you gotta give me some direction man."  Alright. He ended up making a drink that tasted like an ashtray. I mean, I know mescal is smoky but this was disgusting.  I would have asked him to redo it but his horrible attitude and the long wait wasn't worth the bother, so we left having wasted our $15.
author: Mo S.

description: Has hard alcohol, usually not over crowded.  Kinda chill.
author: Michael E.

description: The name clearly set me up to expect itty bitty, but this place is pretty sizeable. There's a little nook of a room in the back where three couches are jammed into a U. Interesting art all along the walls, friendly clientele, and clean. Dog-friendly bar since there was a sad pooch wandering around being confused. Even dive scenesters could like this place!
author: Kevin L.

description: This place is small and dark, but in a good way. The back room is very cozy. So cozy, in fact, that I may or may not have fallen asleep there one night. Anyway...the drinks are affordable, and it's located in a great neighborhood. I'll definitely see you again, little guy.
author: Kamila A.

description: My go-to neighborhood spot.  Never too crowded (but I go on the early end of the night), great service, and reasonable prices.  Not much more to say...
author: Allison P.

description:
Summer the season isn't my cup of tea, but Sommer the bartender is money!  Having a drink at Mini Bar SF was like unwinding at a small party  in a friend's arty but understated livingroom, and she was the perfect host.

Being a Richmond kid, I expected the other patrons to smell it on me from a mile away with shunning glares awaiting me inside, but to my surprise, it was incredibly nice and laid back.

All that and great daily drink specials?  This could make a regular out of me.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I paid 11 dollars for a Glenlivet 12 on the rocks here. I've paid more, but let me tell you why this sucks so bad. 

It is cramped, there is nowhere to be comfortably out of the way (except the back room, but we looked in there and there were 2-3 dogs running around so we said fuck that) and you're always getting bumped squeezed passed. Somebody said in their review that it is a crime that the bartenders have double the room of the patrons, that is totally true.

The crowd is pretty much uniformly young and hip, lots of plaid, thick glasses and hip jackets in this place. It makes it worse that you can't ignore people you would like to because its so small. I'm not saying I walk into a bar thinking "I don't want to see these people" but when there are people way far ahead on the drunk level and you can't keep your distance it sucks. 

There are comically small tables to sit at. Seriously. I don't think my laptop would fit on one. The only good thing I can say is that I enjoyed 2 of the art pieces on the wall. 

So anyway, I paid double what I pay most places for a simple drink on the rocks and went up to the bar to ask if this was correct. I was thinking that I might have gotten the 18 years bottle instead, which is understandably pricier. I will never know because I was ignored completely and eventually gave up. 

Not great. Over hip, over priced, too small. Two stars.

*****EDIT*****: Contacted by manager, offered a refund for the confusion and a free drink.
author: Jay C.

description: This place was full when my party arrived. We had to stand the whole time, but it was okay because we were there for just 1 drink. We were hoppin around to other similar places in the area. They make a pretty good whiskey sour, not the best i've had but still enjoyed it.
author: Anthony P.

description: It's a cute dive bar and the bartender is super nice. Loved the Raspberry Motijo even though I don't really like mint.
author: Kerry T.

description:
Great local bar. It wasn't too crowded and has a nice nook all the way in the back for intimacy. Definitely a great place to have a drink while you wait for a table at LSP, literally across the street.
The bartender is pretty awesome, looks more biker-esque than anything else. Good guy.
Walking a total of 2 blocks here from home makes it all the better!
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Hmm. I'm gifting Mini Bar three stars since there wasn't really anything wrong per se, I just wasn't feeling it. 

Walking in at around 5pm, I was first surprised by the crowd, and then the dogs. Not until after we sat at one of the narrow, uncomfortable, side bars was it pointed out to me that I was the only female in the place. Not that I mind, just odd, a bar full of boys and dogs. The art on the walls, while not very good overall, felt out of place, what with all the animals running around sniffing at each other. 

Drinks - they had a Tuesday special of Russian River Pliny-The-Elder bottles for $4 which were quite nice, not sure why the bartender felt the need to let us know that NOPA sells it for $9 though. Happy hour is $1 off wine, but my prosecco was a stingier pour than I am used to. 

Overall, not my scene, won't be back. Probably a great bet if you feel the need to imbibe while walking the dog though.
author: Jenn W.

description:
My group stopped in here briefly to check it out.  It was 11PM, there was no music playing, and the layout made the bar cramped.  The drinks were completely forgettable. It did have a very clean ladies room though.

Needless to say we didn't stay long.  With Fly Bar and The Page right down the street I don't think i'll be stopping back in here again.
author: Lara O.

description:
I just moved to the neighborhood and was really missing my old hood standbye, The Argus (best drinks in SF!), when I finally popped into Mini Bar. I'm hooked. Love the place. Cheap drinks, neighborhood vibe. 

The bar is small, limited seating, not a lot going on. People come here with friends or to meet friends or grab a solo drink. I wouldn't recommend this place if you're looking for a crazy party (although you could meet someone that would lead you to that...). 

There is also artwork by local artists on the wall. Don't come here with pretensions.
author: Rena B.

description:
Of course I finally get a full bar in my neighborhood.

Only to have me move to a different neighborhood.

I'm an idiot.
author: Matthew R.

description:
Comfortable and laid back, no cliquey feeling.
A+ for serving Russian River beers.
author: Lauren M.

description:
To me Mini Bar is like a Pop Tart.

So hot it's cool.  So cool it's hot.

Great concept and execution.  Simple but yet refined.  Great jovial crowd.  Good presentation of pretty damn good art.  Solid bar and barkeeps.  Loungy space without pretenses.  It is actually quite small without feeling cramped.

It is just a cool place...that you'll be excited to go each time.
author: Chris D.

description:
I went into the Mini Bar on a recent trip to SF after checking with Yelp to find a good bar in the area.  Since it had four stars, my friends and I went inside to have a drink.  Wow, the Mini Bar is lame.  I have no idea why anyone would give this place four stars.  

SF is an amazing city with a lot of incredible places to hang out at, I'm not sure why anyone would want to hang out at Mini Bar.  Lame drinks.  Lame service (yes you Mr. Bartender, you're a dick).  Lame vibe.  And what's up with all that bad art on the wall? 

Do yourself a favor.  Skip this place.
author: B P.

description:
It's taken me too long to stop in here, given that it's now the closest bar to my house. (about .3 miles, according to Google Maps. I could walk that even if I've lost one of my shoes.) It took Nadja M. who now lives in New York flagging me down on the sidewalk to get me to finally try it. I am a terrible local. 

But you know what Mini Bar's got? A full liquor license, cool bartenders (Drew knows his stuff, and has convinced me to give Rye whiskey a second chance), a nicely decorated space, and comfortable seating, and friendly regulars instead of smug aloof hipsters that some of the other neighborhood bars are still sporting. 

Not at all like drinking alone in a hotel room, like you have to with most other mini bars. Except that you can't get away with refilling the gin and vodka bottles with tap water.
author: matthew r.

description:
This place is decent, despite the dearth of seating. The two stars are due to one of the bartenders who was nothing short of belligerent after a benign miscommunication with a member of my party. 
His behavior was 100% out of line, for example: he asked my friend to "suck a dick and go back to Fremont!" He also clairvoyantly shouted "you don't have a legit job!" and of course hurled the requisite "douchebag" accusation. Clearly psych-evals are not a pre-req for employment here.

It might be a good place to go, but be prepared to be berated. Or maybe that guy will be on his meds or not wasted-while-working next time.
author: jay m.

description:
One of my favorite bars in the whole city. I tend to love small bars, and mini bar is pretty small. But at the same time, it's deceptively large. There's a "front" area, the bar itself and this crazy cozy secret back room that I've never actually been able to find a seat in . 

Mini bar has been open for, I think, about 2 years now and they've stayed surprisingly true to their premise. A small bar, good friends, good neighbors, and a splash of local art over reasonably priced drinks. The bartenders are very friendly, at least one of them has a pretty awesome taste in music. The drinks are fairly strong but they won't knock ya over (unless you ask for it). They carry a decent amount of respectable beers. And they do push that gimlet on ya for some reason, but it ain't bad. 

I really like that during the annual Noise Pop festival, they host the "art of noisepop" on the walls, which is a bunch of historic promotional posters and what not. Very cool. They also feature lots of great local photographers.

The only reason this bar doesn't get 5 stars is that, like any good thing in this town, it's ruined by the crowds. It's become near impossible to grab a seat here on the weekend, and even Thursday has become a challenge. Yes, I am blaming them for being popular...but lots of people goes against the whole "mini" concept. You can't meet new friends when the person next you already brought his 6 best ones with them. Oh well.
author: Tolga E.

description: Hands down my favorite bar in San Francisco. I did just move here so I haven't seen much, but the other week I went in and it was their 4th anniversary. They had free drinks and food and it was incredible. I got pretty lucky walking in there that day! Their bartenders are always super sweet and the drinks are pretty reasonably priced. My favorite part is that they allow dogs inside. (I assume only when its not too crowded?) Even when the place is packed I love coming here for the atmosphere. Lots of great art to look at and great beers on tap!
author: Rachel T.

description:
Ugh, I promised some folks who live in the neighborhood that I'd give Mini Bar another chance, so I checked it out for a bit on a relatively busy Saturday night. 

I was able to get the bartender's attention pretty quickly, and he was actually pretty cool; I ordered a Kettle One & Soda for my friend and a Hendrick's Martini (up with 2 olives) for myself. I guess he had to run an errand because he then stepped out of the bar and another person made my martini. Again, she was nice enough, but at nearly $8 per drink, I was expecting a perfectly made cocktail. Instead I got a version that was at once too dirty and too sweet. Maybe I'm used to drinking at Absinthe or NOPA, but to me a martini is that classic that just has to be done right. 

If you do go, try and go early and get the front booth, seems like a good spot to enjoy a few drinks with friends.
author: Nish N.

description:
Not much of a barfly, but I *love* this place.  It has been my "local" since I moved to the neighborhood and so far only Mojo comes close to rivaling it.  Cozy, chill, unpretentious, lovely mixed crowd (i.e., no discernable "scene"), friendly bartenders, small but solid selection of beers (including Racer  5 and a seasonal from Magnolia) and they let you bring delicious Little Star pizzas (or any other local takeaway) in from right across the street.  I'd feel comfortable bringing anyone here, from die-hard hipsters to Marina dwellers.  Sometimes the art is great (I've even thought about buying the occasional piece) and it's always at least decent.

As others have noted, our little neighborhood straddling Lower Haight, USF/Panhandle and the Western Addy is gentrifying and it isn't clear what the ensuing results will be, but regardless I hope this place remains the gem that it is.
author: Tee Jay R.

description:
Mini Bar, Maxi Fun!

I dig this place. You can call it the Little Star waiting room or a pre-party spot before a show at the Independent...either way, it's a cool space packed mainly with locals (Hi Gabe!) that not only features a full bar but also rotating art on the walls.

Good stuff, I'll be back.
author: phil h.

description:
Came here after Bar 821 closed up early.  They have a full bar, but no cocktail menu so you kind of order blind if you want anything more interesting than a "x and y".  I managed to get the bartender to recommend something and she made me a fine champs elysees.

Because of the narrow space, there isn't a great place to stand/sit if it's crowded and the back is full, and dang it gets hot in there.  I guess the name kind of says it all.  Closed up at midnight...better than Bar 821, but c'mon people, doesn't anyone stay up late anymore?
author: Stephen D.

description: A slight taste of Texas. Queso Mondays uh-huh. Lone star on ice yup. Great staff and cozy seats.
author: Martin M.

description:
Hmm.  This place does not have miniature bottles of Jack Daniels that will set my hotel bill way over the limit.  False advertising.

Actually, I didn't find it all that minature in general.  The passage along the bar was narrow, I'll give it that.  The result being that people are forcibly friendly here, but I think they'd be anyway.  There's thousand+ dollar5X8 (inch!)* art on the wall, so you have to figure the clientele's just a little more classy than your run-o-the-mill place.  Even if it is pop design on wood paneling.

Bartender poured a great drink and served it with a smile.  Other patrons all seemed to be in a good mood.  Word around the bar is, this place is popular.  Or is that just the narrow passage?

My recently developed philosophy** about this place is: Pop in, it might be hoppin.

*OK, sort of "mini"
**recently developed philosophies should rhyme whenever possible.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
4.5 stars!
I'm slowly falling in _.O.V.E with this place.
We stopped in quickly to decompress after work before
heading out to dinner. A great, funky and cute crowd
much like the neighborhood. Lots of daily happy hour specials
and as always comfy booths and friendly barkeeps.
I totally man-browsed on the DL and noticed that there were 
many cute single boys in attendance(tuesday night)
I totally wanted to call one of my very fun and very
single BFFs' to meet us and scope out the scene.
But alas, we were only there for one round :(
Next time I'll drag her along. . . .
author: Kia B.

description: what a great neighborhood gem. I came in here for the release of Russian River's Pliny the Younger and after a couple pints of that 11% deliciousness we were very happy that little star was across the street! I'd totally stop in for a drink if I was in the area and really love little neighborhood bars like this that feature local artwork on the walls.
author: Mike K.

description: I love this cozy little spot! Came here on a Thursday night and there were just a few people at the bar, a couple dogs hanging out in the front room and no mmtss mmmtsss music to keep you from hearing your friends. We snagged some seats in the small back room, which kinda reminds me of sitting in a college apartment, but with fun artwork instead of posters. Two thumbs up. Oh, and it doesn't hurt that the bathrooms are clean.
author: Karena Q.

description:
It's okay. 
 And for your information anything from Haight to California  and Masonic to Octavia was the Fillmore or the MO for short  before all of the new comers decided the neighborhood needed to be unidentified with the former residents, got it.  And NOPA is the most ridiculous name of late.
author: ahsal a.

description: local art was in my opinion very good. the floor needed to be painted.aside from that the drinks were good. first time i had a whiskey sour made from scratch in a long time. the bar snacks were worth paying for. definitely will be back.
author: scott c.

description:
Who can resist the lure of the Mini Bar? All of those pretty bottles...funny snacks...

Not me.  This is my favorite new bar in the city.  We've been a couple of times and it has just the right vibe:  unpretentious, neighborhood-y, various choices of seating arrangements, local art.  Excellent Women's restroom.  

This is a long bar, so you have to keep your body to one side and keep the pathway in mind.  Do this, and you can park yourself indefinitely for a fun and fairly chill evening.

Even when full, you can still hear your companions.  Key.

The location is right across the street from Little Star Pizza (mmmm), and unlike Bar 821 which I do like, it is a full, hard alcohol-laden, bar.  If you need this, you know who you are, and will be as happy as we were to have this option in this neighborhood.  Something for everyone, and a good beer selection which I always appreciate.

Now, don't you all go crowding this bar up as I intend to patronize it frequently and don't want to have to fight for space, but feel free to visit when you are in the neighborhood.
author: Liz S.

description: Mini Bar has the feel of a dive, but without the grunginess.  The space is optimized by counter and couch seating in addition to the bar.  The art adds a nice touch to the mostly gray interior.  The full bar and decent selection of beer make this bar a-ok.
author: Sandy K.

description:
after the disappointment that was previously hailed as one of the best fights of the century...(you go golden boy promotions!!!) it was necessary to find some real entertainment tonight in nopa.

the options discussed were- flybar, 821 and minibar.

all spaces are tight and not so great for a decompression forum amongst the 7 of us, we went with minibar cos it has more than just beer and soju.

the crowd was not so mixed, but everyone seemed pretty cool and i was immediately greeted by the cool tender chica that was already serving two other patrons.

lori, dan and chest were able to jump on the tight little booth area near the door as a party was leaving and we nestled in nicely tho once our other three compadres made it there, two of us were standing while the rest were chillaxin in comfort.

the sapphire tonics made were hella strong but still tasty.  we all roamed on topics from joy division to geto boys to the eventual return of grunge then to the whole rockband phenomenon...we all couldn't help but continually put all of our attention to the photography on the wall, supposedly from a past Playboy shooter...and thx again friend for making us all throw up in our mouth a lil by talking about the model being a tucked dood, not a woman..ewwww

i was just happy to be surrounded by my pals on a fine sf evening and to top it off i noticed The New(interpol) playing in the background..YEAHYAH!! sommer, one of the owners cruised by to chatty chat and pick up empties...again suuper-fly staff!
author: omar b.

description:
I like Mini Bar. The mini bottles of booze at the top of the bar are cute and what I'm assuming to be the reference for the name since the place itself is not so small. Even on a bustling Friday night, we were able to pull up a seat at the bar. It wasn't so loud that we couldn't hold an intimate conversation, even at the bar.

The mojitos we ordered were fresh and tasty. The bartender even offered to sweeten up mine on the spot if it was a little too tart. On round #2 of ordering or round #5+ of drinking [We'd had several rounds earlier in the night.], one of the ingredients in the drink I ordered wasn't readily available, so she improvised. It's nice to walk into a place, knowing that they care about the drinks they are serving.

If I lived in the area, I'd visit regularly and make it my mini bar... Drinks aren't ridiculously priced. I'd also get my grubby fingers on the Pirate's Booty too.
author: Tinna H.

description:
I am reviewing the Art element of the Bar.  I did not drink there since I don't drink.

I stopped by to check out the art.  I loved the work in the back upper room.  It is done by a furniture artist who did a great job of hanging carved wooden furniture on the walls and even designed the wooden coffee table in the back.  Innovative way of showing utilitarian art work.  

I love that the shotgun style architecture was welcoming and had some really nice hanging art work in the front bar gallery.  It is a great idea to create space withing a space.  

The space is nice yet not uptight. Love the simple decor and bi-level bar layout.  Small but cute. It was not busy when I went in around 4:30 during a weekday.  

Minus for me:   However I am not into socializing with dogs  and other 4 legged animals in public facilities (allergies. and other health/safety concerns) so if you have allergies to doggies you might want to skip this place, they allow them in the space.
author: Vanilla C.

description: Reasonably priced drinks, not Castro-strong, but acceptable. ($5 sidecar) Music is not anything to write home about, but it didn't interfere with conversation. It was a bit crowded, but it's the price you pay for quality.
author: Nikolas B.

description:
Seriously?

Nu Metal?

The guy that works your fucking door is AWESOME and into black metal....and you abuse him with the musical stylings of Papa Roach, Trapt and the like?

Course, that was one night....but just saying...nu metal is a disease that leaves a dirty trail for a long long time.

The first time i went in here, it was election night, and i ran in screaming "OBAAAMMMAAA!!!" where the doorguy chased my silly ass out for breaking 9 noise ordinance laws. 

On the total, I have been in here thrice, or fourthce, and each time the bartenders pour quick and strong, like a kick from a mini horse.

The little FauxVIP area in the back is definitely a cool area if you can land it, but be careful....trying to scale down them at Spiderman speeds after your 6th Dewer's rocks makes you look like a slippery wet rat.
author: Mick F.

description:
I'm not going to lie, I've only been here twice and was sober all of none of those times.
However the bartenders are always nice and there was a sassy punk guy working the the door who was really nice.
author: Cailie S.

description: This place is pretty hip. I was caught off guard with their bar dog hanging out with the crowd. This place is small but it works for me.  I forgot what beer I ordered but I thought it'll be draft but $5 for a bottle of beer at the bar? No bueno. Was only here for less than half an hour so I can't say much about this place but it's cool to grab a drink and hang out here if you want a very dim atmosphere.
author: Irene L.

description:
My favorite neighborhood bar!
They have a full bar, unlike most of the other bars in the area that serve only beer and wine. 
Everyone that works here is beyond nice, Molly, Les, Summer take your pick..really a refreshing change in the SF bar scene. 
And best of all they are huge supporters of the neighborhood, putting up new art installations on their walls every 6 weeks provided only by local artists! 
And they support all the great local restaurants by allowing you to bring in your food (pizza from Little Star, lasagna from Herbivore, whatever) to eat while enjoying a tasty brew! 
Cheers to Mini Bar!
author: Linz H.

description:
Mmmm...mmmm...mmm... how I love me some Mini Bar. 

The owners are all amazing and hangout on a daily bases. They also support local business and are trying to make sure there are no problems or loud drunk folks hanging outside their bar (except for me of course). I don't know what it would be like without the doorman. Some folks seem to be hating but I love it. I won't drink beer there (that's what I got 821 for) but damn if I don't have a few double jack and coke in a pint glass with a lime!  I just wish I could wake up early enough on a Saturday or Sunday to try one of their bloody mary's. I know Molly heads down to the farmers market each morning for fresh vegetables. Hmmm... maybe they should start making wake up calls? Holla atcha boy!

MMMMmm....mmmm....mmm.... how I love me some Bar, Mini!
author: Jamal G.

description:
Liquor on Divisidaro close to my house.  It has a cute room in back for a more intimate gathering...and we got a makers rocks and a vodka soda for $11.  Pretty reasonable.  And who doesnt love mini things.

The decor is sexy, the couches are leather, and there is local art on the walls....

Everytime I pass by, its never crazy packed either, which makes it much more inviting for me...
author: Lauren F.

description: It is exactly what the name says "Mini Bar", but its spirit is anything but mini. Great place. I really enjoyed it. Like I said it's a bit small and  even though it can sometimes take a bit of time to get your drink it's worth it.
author: M R.

description:
I've now been to mini-bar a few times although I don't think it was open yet when I used to live 3 blocks from it.

It's a great place for happy hour (although I'm not sure of their happy hour specials) with a few friends but probably not the place for a large gathering since it is kind of small.  Sure there might be an incentive to reserve the back room but this seems more like a launch pad for a longer evening.  Meet for some drinks and then head out somewhere else along Divisadero for some grub or something.

The atmosphere in this place is real nice too.  They have art work up and some of it seems to be WIP (like the bottle caps and Muni passes next to the bathroom).  The can collage on the wall near the bar is super cool too.

Only backdraw is size so if it gets a little packed you might be waiting a few minutes for a drink.
author: James G.

description:
Us Bar 821 regulars didn't take kindly to the idea of another bar opening up almost next door. We were standoffish, we were suspicious, we were downright talking shit. But then I moved away from the neighborhood and therefore no longer care :)

At a friend's insistence (persistent insistance, I might add), I finally made my way over to what is actually a not-so-mini bar. I mean the place is narrow but it's like a cave- it goes pretty far back. It may even be the same square footage as 821. The bar is attractive and they have a prosecco (which was interpreted as "percocet" when I ordered it...) that's actually pretty tasty. Unlike 821, these guys have real booze, which makes Mini a dangerous destination for me, especially on a school night.

Overall, it's a pretty cool space. The actual bar is a little small and seating in the front comfy booths can be hard to come by but there's also an upstairs space with couches and chairs. I was three sheets to the wind upon arrival, so I really can't give much more detail but I'll definitely be back.
author: Autumn K.

description:
I had a great time here while waiting for my table at Little Star. Unlike most of the other places in San Francisco, I wasn't treated like shit, which was a nice change of pace. James hooked it up with a delicious variation on the Old Fashioned. I also got a taste of the homemade Bloody Mary mixes that I am looking forward to imbibing this upcoming weekend.

There is a little lounge area with couches that look like goooood sittin. I will enjoy it. 

Go Mini Bar! Also, whoever "Larry" is (you know, the guy below me with 2 reviews and no friends)....yea, he is a douchebag.
author: N S.

description:
The ambiance rates five stars, but the service and cocktails both get one from me.   If you end up at the Mini Bar, stick to drinking beer.  

I first wandered in here because they were having a No-on-8 fundraiser.  Great vibe that night.  I wisely ordered a beer, which was fine.  

The second night, I ordered a Manhattan.  The bartender (short tattoeed guy with dark-rimmed glasses) was a dick and made the worst Manhattan I've ever had.  He acted like I was interrupting him and his friends by trying to order a drink.

The manhattan tasted like Robitussin in an up-glass.  I think the bartender must've poured a full ounce of maraschino cherry syrup into my drink.  This was the sweetest, nastiest manhattan I've ever had.  Also, they put two cherries into the smallest up glass on Divisadero.  So most of what you're buying is fruit, not bourbon.  

They do the same with their martinis.  Two olives in a real small glass.  If I want an olive plate, I'll order an olive plate.   If I want to drink, I'll go somewhere besides the Mini-Bar

If you need a cocktail on Divisadero, go to the Page or Madrone or Waziema.
author: Penelope D.

description: Great bartender - friendly and ready to make up a drink for you on the spot.  Nice neighborhood spot to hang out with your dog after a long walk.
author: Buttonwillow M.

description: A local gem of a drinking establishment.  Awesome art, comfy couches, sweet staff, sociable regulars, and strong drinks.  I fell "in like" with my now boyfriend there and I think his allure may have been half this bar's fault.  Do it!
author: Erin M.

description:
ok, I have tried this place twice and am not impressed at all. In fact, we are starting a pool to see how long it will be open! 
The first time I went in, it was almost the end of Happy Hour. The super snobby bartender refused to look up to acknowledge anyone was waiting for her servitude and then decided they were no longer going to honor happy hour prices, so we left.
The seconf time, the security guard almost fell off his chair and had SUCH an attitude like he was working at a NYC club- Please, this is only NOPA, not the Village. Once again, took forever to get bartenders attention. Nice they have a full bar,artwork is fantastic as is  the design, but the attitude needs to stop.
author: M L.

description:
As a big fan of its neighbor, Bar 821, Mini Bar had a lot to live up to in my eyes.  And while similar in a lot of ways, both have its share of unique qualities.  

Mini's biggest advantage is in serving hard liquor, and a few--albeit, healthy (Pirate Booty, and the like)--snacks to munch on.  The space has more couch seating, allowing patrons a larger area to relax.  Compared to next door, the bartender here was a chatty Cathy; alone or not, she'll strike up a conversation with you, regardless.  Local art graces the walls, which are also available for purchase on the spot.

Although I gravitate towards 821 for their $3 Happy Hour cocktails, I always found the small place more conducive to grabbing a quick drink and jetting.  The atmosphere at Mini Bar, on the other hand, seems comfortable enough to lounge around at all night.  Either way, both attract a mellow, neighborhood crowd.  Given how pretentious some bars in this city can be, sometimes, that's all you can ask for.
author: Marsha Z.

description: This place frakin' rules and anyone who says otherwise is a damn liar!
author: Gabriel F.

description:
Well, I started writing a review for Mini Bar three weeks ago after my first drop in for a whiskey post birthday dinner with roommates past & present. I stopped a few sentences in & haven't come back to it until now. Why is this important? Because I've been back to Mini Bar THREE times since. It's effectively around the corner from my old house, serves liquor (lord knows I love my whiskey), & the environment is cozy & unpretentious. Additionally, they've got some killer art on the walls from neighborhood artists, the owners are incredibly nice people who have lived in the 'hood for more than a decade & can often be found mingling with the clientele. The list goes on & on & on.

A Welcome Addition to the Western Addition.
author: Pete J.

description:
My new favorite neighborhood bar!  It's cozy, friendly and hip all at the same time.   Plus the bartenders are cheerful, knowledgeable and enjoy experimenting.

Bartender: What'll you have?
Me: I dunno. Something with whiskey.
Bartender: Ok. Anything you don't like?
Me: Cherry. Blech. Nothing too sweet.
Bartender: Don't worry, I'd never do that to you.  

I felt so safe and cared for! :)  A nice feeling, at a bar.  Moments later he presented me with a lovely little concoction that I didn't even know I'd wanted. 

Other perks: Cool, local art.  Reasonable prices.  Friendly locals.  Plush booths.  Sparkling mirrored bar.
author: Wes P.

description: I dig this cute little place. It's a great local hangout spot, especially on weekdays. They have good daily specials and friendly bartenders that actually remember your previous drink orders. Of all the handful of times I've been there, I've had a great time....But maybe it's because there is some good eye candy there. As a straight lady, I was flabbergasted to find a place that actually had straight, single men....Shhhh, don't tell anyone.
author: Sarah L.

description:
What I like about the Mini Bar: the vibe, the decor, the art, the drinks, the peeps. 

Laid back and unpretencious. Score the back room if you can. 

Ask for a "gopher's butt." It's delicious! aka Mango gimlet.
author: Misha F.

description:
I send the husband here when I need him out of the house.  Sometimes I even join in.  Happy hour is a great deal.  I like their beer selections and that the specials are something they've tried and not just gotten a deal from their distributor.

Great ownership and a great addition to the block!
author: M M.

description: Aside from having some awesome bartenders... Mini is located in one of the greatest neighborhoods of SF.  Come in here to get a relaxing drink (if you can find a seat on the more busy days...) and view the local art that is on display regularly. Definitely a cozy neighborhood chill spot. Not to be placed in the same category as Page Bar on Divisadero which is more of a pool table, beer guzzling, jukebox hang out.
author: Sarina U.

description: Want to like this place. But we've been 3 times and that will be our last. Overall, it's hard to feel comfortable (though the back room is nice), it's loud, and the staff can be a mixed bag. It's not awful but there's nothing special. The kicker was during beer week when they were serving Pliny the Younger. They had run out but continued to serve flights - that's fine but instead of letting me know they were out of the Younger when I ordered, the bartender just served me four glasses instead of five. So then I had to ask where the fifth glass was and received in return, literally, a snort, an eye roll, and a terse "We're out." Gee thanks, sorry I bothered you.
author: Katie M.

description:
This is mostly a review, but I can't help but start with a rant.  And that is regarding the over use of the term "hipster", which a couple people have referred to Mini Bar as and I feel like has become the defacto description for things contemporary, urban, artistic or just beyond someones experience.  

Mini Bar appeared to me to be rather cozy, though the decor is contempo-loungey and showcases a collection of art by different rotations of artists (unfortunately they chose to display the worst paintings on the only wall you can see if you're sitting down).  They don't have a cocktail list, which seemed odd (they're all about the cocktail), but the service was efficient and when we got a seat it was primo and looked out onto the street.  I would go here again when I'm next in the neighborhood and know exactly what I want to drink.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
The bartender Randy is a complete douche bag.  
It was flat out the worst experience I've ever had with a server or bartender.  If he is working I strongly recommend going elsewhere.
author: Larry M.

description:
Great place to go with a small group of people for a few drinks and a little conversation.  It certainly has a very regular crowd that you will see pretty much every time you go in, but they are friendly and welcoming.  The atmosphere is cozy, dark and artsy, with ever changing artwork on the walls and a quaint little back room, and as the name may hint, it is quite small.
My only dislikes are that the beers are all about $0.50 over priced and my party was once told to keep it down, so as to not disturb the neighbors.  I went to Mini Bar to not disturb my neighbors, now I have to worry about theirs?
author: Dan L.

description:
Everything I could ask for in a drinking establishment. Well-made drinks, excellent bartender and a bestest friend to vent with. It's the size of a dive bar, but not-smelly, not-dark or -dank, and not-full-of-hipster-irony. 

I'm a fan of little efforts that mean a lot. We were sitting at the bar chatting away when we ordered our second round. By this time, we were 45 minutes past the end of Happy Hour, but the bartender indicated that she'd discount our next round anyway. 

Honestly, it only cost her $2 (which we then added back into the tip), but it's those small things that make a big difference. 

And, it's those small things that will keep me coming back.
author: Erin M.

description:
This little warm bar is just fabulous! Not only did they allow us to bring our pooch Bob, but they gave us the back room for our little bday party gratis! And, get this, asked if we needed anything. What? I said. Yes, they asked if we needed plates or plastic ware. I could not believe my ears. 

The bartenders are very warm and friendly and really down to earth. No pretension. All goodness and grey and warm and good. Just good. 

This is the little bar that could.
author: Christina R.

description: I just moved to the Nopa area and this  a great local bar to grab a drink and catch up with friends.  Bartenders are nice, the environment is laid back and the crowd is chill.  They also allow dogs from what I heard and they also have art on display to view and purchase, overall great experience, will be going back.
author: David K.

description:
Pluses: Decent happy hour, not too crowded on week nights. Full bar.

Negatives: Can't imagine how crammed this place gets when more than 15 people walk into this place!  The music they play sucks (Pinback, anyone?) and the over ambiance is just plain, well, plain.
author: Scott G.

description: Love Art Bars! Keep an eye out if your going to this place cause you might miss it, from the street it doesn't look like much, but go inside. Lots of variety in the local art from sculptures, paintings on the wall and canvas to skateboards. Art makes the atmosphere but as the name says it's pretty small. My favorite place to sit is in the far back, it has steps up and its a cozy setting, with a comfortable and seats, good for a small group to hang. Sometime it gets too packed and uncomfortable to drink wine when people are bumping into you if your standing. Its nice if you want to get dressed up or a special occasion and go out. Usually no cover charge, but we were there on New Years Eve it's expected everywhere, just arrived before 10 so it was free.
author: Monica M.

description:
Met up with friends here in the back room for a birthday. I just was not impressed.

The back room has no music, so there wasn't much of an atmosphere. The lock on the bathroom door was broken, so friends would have to post up outside to watch out for each other. I don't usually notice the art much, but all agreed that the stuff here was pretty much ugly and awful. 

Some drunk folks were yelling and being obnoxious at the bar, and because it's so small it was loud as hell. I don't know why they weren't thrown out.
author: Adam Z.

description:
I finally have a full bar near my house!
